question: [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::new()] [Verification bypass] Can an attacker bypass the module verification check by providing a ModuleCode wrapper that falsely reports is_verified() as true while containing unverified bytecode, allowing execution of malicious code? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::new()] [Type confusion] Does the verification check in Entry::new() properly validate the generic type constraints, or can an attacker exploit type parameter confusion to insert deserialized-but-unverified modules into the cache? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::new()] [Race condition] If Entry::new() is called concurrently with module verification completing, can a race condition allow a partially-verified module to be inserted with overridden=false? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::new()] [Panic error handling] Can the PanicError returned by Entry::new() be suppressed or mishandled by calling code, allowing unverified modules to remain accessible in memory? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::new()] [Error message leakage] Does the error message 'Module code is not verified' leak sensitive information about module structure or verification internals that could aid attackers? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::mark_overridden()] [Memory ordering] Does the Ordering::Release in mark_overridden() provide sufficient synchronization guarantees, or can a concurrent reader using Ordering::Acquire miss the update and use stale overridden=false state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::mark_overridden()] [Race condition] Can multiple concurrent calls to mark_overridden() create race conditions where the final state is indeterminate, potentially leaving modules in an inconsistent override state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::mark_overridden()] [Reentrancy] If mark_overridden() is called reentrantly (e.g., during module publishing that triggers other module loads), can the atomic operation be corrupted? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::mark_overridden()] [Irreversibility] Once mark_overridden() sets overridden=true, there's no mechanism to reset it - can this be exploited to permanently DOS access to critical system modules? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::mark_overridden()] [ABA problem] Can an ABA problem occur where overridden is set to true, then a new entry is inserted, but readers still see the old cached overridden state? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::is_not_overridden()] [Memory ordering] Does Ordering::Acquire in is_not_overridden() properly synchronize with Ordering::Release in mark_overridden(), or can reordering cause readers to see overridden=false for already-invalidated modules? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::is_not_overridden()] [TOCTOU] Between checking is_not_overridden() and calling module_code(), can a TOCTOU race allow the module to be marked overridden, causing execution of invalidated code? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::is_not_overridden()] [Cache coherence] On multi-core systems, can CPU cache coherence delays cause is_not_overridden() to return stale true values even after mark_overridden() completes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::is_not_overridden()] [Negation logic] Does the double negation logic (!self.overridden.load()) introduce any edge cases or confusion that could lead to incorrect cache hits? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::module_code()] [Unchecked access] Does module_code() provide direct access without checking is_not_overridden(), allowing callers to bypass override checks and execute invalidated modules? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::module_code()] [Arc clone cost] Can an attacker trigger excessive Arc::clone operations on module_code() to cause memory pressure or performance degradation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::clone_for_fuzzing()] [Production usage] Despite the cfg(fuzzing) guard, can clone_for_fuzzing() be enabled in production builds through feature flag manipulation, exposing Relaxed ordering that lacks synchronization? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: Entry::clone_for_fuzzing()] [Relaxed ordering] Does the use of Ordering::Relaxed in clone_for_fuzzing() create race conditions during fuzzing that could hide real bugs by producing non-deterministic behavior? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: GlobalModuleCache::empty()] [Uninitialized state] Can empty() be called multiple times to reset a cache containing valid modules, causing loss of verified code and forcing re-verification overhead? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: GlobalModuleCache::contains_not_overridden()] [TOCTOU] Between contains_not_overridden() returning true and subsequent get() call, can mark_overridden() invalidate the module, causing inconsistent cache state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: GlobalModuleCache::contains_not_overridden()] [HashMap iteration] Since module_cache is HashMap (not concurrent), can concurrent reads during iteration cause UB or panics in contains_not_overridden()? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: GlobalModuleCache::contains_not_overridden()] [Side channel] Can timing differences between cache hit/miss in contains_not_overridden() leak information about which modules are cached? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: GlobalModuleCache::mark_overridden()] [DOS attack] Can an attacker mark all system modules as overridden to force constant cache misses, degrading performance and potentially halting block execution? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: GlobalModuleCache::mark_overridden()] [No verification] Does mark_overridden() require any access control checks, or can any transaction mark arbitrary modules as overridden? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/code_cache_global.rs] [Function: GlobalModuleCache::mark_overridden()] [Silent failure] When mark_overridden() is called on non-existent keys, it's a no-op - can this silent failure hide bugs or attacks? (Medium)
